title: What will the short-term interest rate be for Australia (AUS) in October 2017?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Shifting toward the middle due to consensus, a terrible reason but I need one.

Rate held at October 17 meeting and low GDP growth indicate likely lower rates:
https://tradingeconomics.com/australia/interest-rate
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
After reconsidering the daily rate data and some of the other forecasts on here, I am increasing my confidence in the middle band.
Daily rate shows steady at or around 1.70 through 10/19.
Today, 1.70, and it has been with in the middle band all month.
Incorporating more of the GJ consensus and updated daily data from https://www.rba.gov.au/statistics/tables/#interest-rates
I am still working on refining this forecast, but given the insight from @cmeinel, I think an adjustment down from my prior forecasts is appropriate.

A little bird gave me data on daily short term interest rates, hence extremizing to 100%.  Little birdie also explained with data in hand, er, beak, that the reason so many sources give 1.71 as the rate for Sept. must be that it was there at the end of the month, while the average was 1.7247619048.  Please tell me why I'm wrong now! Calling all little birdies! @joew92 @sevedb @dsarin @The_Gnome @cdob63 (whom I suspect of a nearly pure follow the top forecasters strategy but who also often posts good info) @AB747 @fburdine @patrickmeehan5 @shivadiva @OdinYoda @Raahul_Kumar @SneakyPete @Censusguyz @Muratabu

1.72 for September. I like what @joew92 (Joe Wood) has done with "extemizing" the lowest bin to zero. Right now I'm regretting having been so low in "More than 1.72" as the rate was on that knife's edge in Sept., according to the OECD data, which will be used to resolve this question.  On the other hand, every other source I've found claims the rate for Sept. was 1.71. Considering the pros and cons, I've decided that Joe Wood's occupation suggests that he might be a better forecaster on this topic than I would be using only my own judgment. So that's the long and the short of why I'm raising probability of over 1.72.
I am 'extremizing' my prior forecast by prorating the bin with <10% probability to the other bins.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
As @sevedb has pointed out at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/592105, the rate has been remarkably steady. Given only two weeks to question closure, a black swan seems highly unlikely.
Following the trend I would estimate 1.81.
Based upon google searches of historical data and forecasts
I haven't decided my confidence level completely. But it's near this given the data.
AUD strengthens as China invests more at home and in Oz as it pulls out of North Korea
RBA won't hike in the immediate future so money market rates will remain stable. T-bills more likely to go up rather than down with AUD depreciating against other major currencies.

Cash rate is at 1.50%
https://www.finder.com.au/rba-cash-rate So the lowest bucket is right out, but the top two buckets are both in play.  This year cash rate dipped down to 1.70% -1.72 4 times. 1.780	1.780	1.790	1.770	1.730	1.720	1.700	1.700	1.720
https://data.oecd.org/interest/short-term-interest-rates.htm

Absent an intervention or macro shock, rates will stay within the 1.68 to 1.75.  The rate had a base of 1.70 through the summer, down from 1.790 in the spring.  There are political rumblings about action, but absent an economic shock that is unlikely in the next 22 days. August-September 17 ended at 1.72.  http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/economics/reserve-bank-of-australia-still-not-ruling-out-rate-cut/news-story/59a48e6fbf87919d3b5c8738dbd25991 Looks like Australian leaders are concerned about wage growth: http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/economics/reserve-bank-of-australia-still-not-ruling-out-rate-cut/news-story/59a48e6fbf87919d3b5c8738dbd25991 The market is pricing in a 25 basis point increase before November 2018: http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-09-05/rba-rates-on-hold/8872606 Though the question asks for short-term rates (and not yields), here is a good primer on factors that can drive rates over time: http://www.frbsf.org/economic-research/publications/economic-letter/2011/november/interest-rate-structure/

The monetary policy decision statement from the RBA gives a good indication of the economy: http://www.rba.gov.au/media-releases/2017/mr-17-21.html
Key points: 
• Australia’s terms of trade are expected to decline in the period ahead. 
• Slow growth in real wages and high levels of household debt are likely to constrain growth in household spending. 
• Inflation remains low 
• Following some tightening in credit conditions, growth in borrowing by investors has slowed a little recently. 
• Employment has continued to grow strongly over recent months. “The Australian dollar fell 0.7% after speculation the central bankers would consider a further cut to interest rates if economic conditions worsened”.https://www.ft.com/content/d169b301-3647-320c-a6d7-dcd220d3391e?mhq5j=e7
A depreciating exchange rate is what the RBA is looking for to help the economy transition after coming out of a mining-investment boom, so I will continue to watch the exchange rate over the next few weeks.

I came up with a few different forecasts and just averaged out the results. All in all, it seems that short-term interest rates have really stabilized between 1.7 and 1.8 since the Reserve Bank of Australia set the cash rate at 1.5 in August 2016.

at first glance this seems like a crapshoot but the rate in the last year has rarely moved more than 0.01 points in a month. So I am going to hope that this trend keeps up but considering how many interest rate questions I seem to get wrong I may need to just stop answering them altogether.
A bit of a gamble going in at 100% but, housing price is high, inflation higher than germany, canda and france so think they will likly raise raise.
Based on the trends from OECD data. It's been in the 1.68-1.72 range for the past 4 months, and above 1.72 in the previous year before that.
